title: Arran Coghlan acted 'reasonably to defend himself' when Stephen Akinyemi was shot dead, inquest rules

A businessman 'was acting reasonably to defend himself' when a suspected gangster was killed with his own gun during a fight, a coroner has ruled. 
Security worker Stephen “Aki” Akinyemi, 44, was shot in the left temple during the tussle with his friend Arran Coghlan on February 9, 2010. 
The fight took place in Mr Coghlan’s home, a converted chapel in Alderley Edge , Cheshire, where he had arranged a meeting to try and end a feud between Mr Akinyemi and another man, who cannot be named for legal reasons. 
Mr Coghlan, 45, who is 6ft 4in, and the muscular Mr Akinyemi, who was 5ft 10in and had been on the verge of becoming a professional boxer, fought in a small and dark ensuite bathroom, the inquest at London’s Royal Courts of Justice was told. 
Mr Akinyemi, who had studied martial arts and been a competitive body builder, was wearing body armour under his clothes, but Mr Coghlan would not have had time to be aware of this as they grappled, Coroner Bernard Richmond QC said. 
At the end of the inquest on Thursday, the coroner rejected short form conclusions of misadventure, lawful or unlawful killing or accidental death to deliver a narrative conclusion. Stephen 'Aki' Akinyemi 
He told the court: “Stephen Akinyemi, in an attempt to coerce a third party into a course of action, produced a gun to reinforce his demand. 
“During the struggle for control of the gun, in which the third party was acting reasonably to defend himself, the gun - which was at all times held by Mr Akinyemi and whose finger was on the trigger, was discharged four times. 
“One of those discharges caused a bullet to go into Stephen Akinyemi’s head, fatally wounding him.” 
Mr Coghlan told a previous inquest in October 2011 that Mr Akinyemi pulled a gun on him and it went off during a struggle in which he got stabbed several times. 
Cheshire Coroner Nicholas Rheinberg recorded an open verdict, saying he had 'difficulty' accepting Mr Coghlan’s version of events. The Alderley edge home of Arran Coghlan 
But following an application by Mr Coghlan for judicial review to the High Court in February 2012, that inquest was quashed and a fresh one was ordered with a different coroner. 
Mr Coghlan was initially accused of murdering Mr Akinyemi. 
But the Crown Prosecution Service dropped the charge because it could not prove Mr Coghlan, who suffered stab wounds to his arms and neck, was not acting in self-defence. 
Delivering his conclusion at the end of the second inquest, Mr Richmond said he was satisfied that Mr Akinyemi and Mr Coghlan, who had known each other since the 1990s, had been on good terms when the fatal fight occurred. Read More Stephen Akiyemi 'died instantly' after being shot in Arran Coghlan's bathroom, inquest hears 
Mr Coghlan was hoping to act as a mediator between his friend and another man over nicknames. 
The pair both had Porsches with number plates containing the contested moniker, the second inquest had previously heard. 
Mr Richmond said it was “highly significant” that Mr Coghlan chose to broker the deal at his home as he was satisfied that he would never have invited his friend to the house had he suspected he was carrying a weapon or intended violence. 
But it was unclear if Mr Coghlan ever invited the other man to turn up at the house, perhaps hoping to persuade his friend to accept the deal without a face-to-face meeting, Mr Richmond said. Arran Coghlan 
He had texted him saying 'Don’t pick up' before calling him, and pretended he had not got through when the man answered the phone, the inquest heard. 
Mr Richmond said that Mr Coghlan’s conduct had been 'necessary and reasonable' in response to a sequence of events that unfolded 'unexpectedly and very quickly' seven years ago. 
He also found that the businessman was someone who valued his friends and was loyal to them. 
Mr Akinyemi could be violent and a bully, and had a propensity to carry knives, the coroner said, but was also a “lovely and much-loved” family man. Read More Arran Coghlan tells inquest he shot Stephen ‘Aki’ Akinyemi - who was armed with gun and knife - during bathroom fight 
Extending his condolences to the family, he remarked that any untimely death was a tragedy. 
After the ruling, which Mr Coghlan was in court for, his lawyer David Mason QC addressed the coroner on behalf of his client. 
He thanked Mr Richmond for his thorough handling of the inquest, which had been a “long and difficult journey”. 
He added that the ruling had restored Mr Coghlan’s faith in the justice system, which was shaken following the first inquest. Like us on Facebook
